CCT La Plata, CONICET 47 Nº 257 La Plata 1900 Argentina In this work, Pt catalysts were prepared using a sol-gel synthesized SiO2 modified by inclusion of tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) and tungstosilicic acid (TSA), which were evaluated in the glycerol hydrogenolysis in liquid phase to obtain 1,3-propylene glycol (1,3-PG) and 1-propanol (1-POH). The results showed that the SiO2 presents a mesoporous and amorphous structure which, modified by inclusion of TPA and TSA, exhibits [H3-xPW12O40]x- (x = 0–3) and [H4-xSiW12O40]x- (x = 0–4) anions with Keggin structure type. The inclusion of TPA or TSA generates strong acid sites and enhances Pt dispersion in the Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts, which have smaller and similar particle sizes ranging from 1.5 to 2.9 nm depending on the heteropolyacid content. On their surface, the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts present a low number of strong acid sites composed by [W2O7]2- and W2O5 species while the Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts present a greater number of sites, but with lower acid strength, composed mainly by [W2O6]2-, H4SiW12O40 and [W7O24]−6 species. The Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts were more active but less stable than the Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts, both series being selective to 1,3-PG and 1-POH. The sintering of the support, the adsorption of glycerol molecules and the leaching of W were identified as the main causes of deactivation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Platinum Heteropolyacids Glycerol 1,3-propylene glycol 1-propanol Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The environmental impact generated by the use of fossil fuels has led society to become aware of their possible consequences and of the need to seek sustainable alternatives for obtaining chemical products and energy. In this way, the search for alternative sources has been encouraged to replace, in part, the current dependence on non-renewable sources. In particular, for more than ten years now, biodiesel has been the biofuel whose production has experienced the highest growth worldwide, with an estimated production of 40 million tons by 2026, 12 % more than the production in 2016 [1]. This expansion has been observed in countries such as Germany, Italy, France and the United States, in addition to others such as Brazil, Indonesia and Malaysia [2]. In particular, Argentina is the fifth largest producer of this biofuel in the world, using a large-scale technology that places it among the most efficient in the world [3]. From the chemical point of view, biodiesel consists of a mixture of esters from long-chain fatty acids, produced from a catalytic transesterification reaction, using virgin or used vegetable oils or animal fats and short-chain alcohols, such as methanol, ethanol or 1-propanol [4]. For every 10 kg of biodiesel produced, 10 kg of triglyceride source and 1 kg of alcohol are required, generating as a by-product 1 kg of crude glycerol with a purity that varies in the range of 55–90 %, due to the presence of traces of triglycerides, alcohol, soaps and catalyst, among others [5]. Glycerol is a polyol with three hydroxyl groups and interesting physicochemical properties that allow its application in different fields, such as the production of medicinal drugs, cosmetics, polymers, food, resins and detergents. Due to its wide availability and low cost, the search for new alternatives for the transformation of glycerol is very attractive [6]. Its chemical functionality makes it a platform molecule for obtaining valuable chemical products through different processes, such as oxidation [7], reforming [8], acetalization [9], esterification [10] and hydrogenolysis [11]. Of all the processes mentioned, catalytic hydrogenolysis is an interesting alternative due to the high oxygen content in the glycerol molecule (O/C = 1). In this sense, the breaking of C-O bonds of glycerol leads to the formation of C3 products such as 1,3-propylene glycol (1,3-PG), 1,2-propylene glycol (1,2-PG) and 1-propanol (1-POH), although the breaking of C-C bonds is also present, allowing the generation of other low molecular weight alcohols such as ethanol (EtOH) and methanol (MeOH). Of these, the C3 products are the most valuable due to their multiple applications. 1,3-PG is used for the production of polyethers, polyesters, polycarbonates and polyurethanes, which represents more than 50 % of its productive application. At present, 1,3-PG is mainly obtained from petrochemical processes (Shell/Degussa-DuPont), although fermentative processes have also been used (DuPont) [12]. 1,2-PG, on the other hand, is used in the chemical, food, cosmetics and pharmaceutical industries and is currently obtained from the hydration of propylene oxide [11]. With respect to 1-POH, it is used as an additive in the manufacture of printing inks, antifreeze, brake fluids and cosmetic lotions, as well as a solvent in the production of gums, lacquers and essential oils. It is now also obtained by a petrochemical route, through the hydroformylation of ethylene [13,14]. The complexity of the petrochemical processes, added to the toxicity of the substances involved in them, leads to consider other alternative routes for obtaining these C3 products. In this regard, glycerol hydrogenolysis offers a route based on the principles of green chemistry and an alternative to traditional petrochemical processes, since it could be carried out in a single reaction stage with the design of suitable catalysts. In particular, with respect to the 1,3-PG/1,2-PG couplet, it has been reported that the activation energies for the removal of the primary and secondary -OH groups from the glycerol molecule are very similar (70.9 kcal/mol and 73.2 kcal/mol respectively) and their affinity for protons is almost identical (∼195 kcal/mol). These characteristics, coupled with steric hindrance, make it more difficult to break the secondary C-O bond than the primary bond in the glycerol molecule [15]. Thus, the formation of 1,3-PG is more disadvantaged than the formation of 1,2-PG. As for 1-POH, it is obtained as the end product of hydrogenolysis, and can be derived from 1,2-PG or 1,3-PG. Whether to obtain glycols or propanol, the process requires a bifunctional catalyst composed of a support with suitable acid-base properties to form the reaction intermediates, and a metallic phase that allows its hydrogenation. With respect to the metallic phase, the use of non-noble metals such as Cu, Ni and Co, was very useful for the formation of 1,2-PG [16,17] and 1-POH [18,19], but impractical for the production of 1,3-PG. Noble metals such as Pt, Ru and Pd have been used interchangeably for the formation of 1,2-PG [20], 1,3-PG [21] and 1-POH [22]. With respect to the support, traditional materials based on SiO2, Al2O3, C, MgO, ZrO2 and zeolites have been used, many of them modified to improve their acid-base properties. In this respect, functionalization or doping techniques with acid solids, such as heteropolyacids, have been used. In this regard, Alhanash et al. were the first to prepare Ru and Rh catalysts supported on Cs2.5H0.5[PW12O40], a heteropolyacid-derived salt. The Ru/Cs2.5H0.5[PW12O40] catalyst proved to be more active than Rh/Cs2.5H0.5[PW12O40], allowing to obtain high selectivity at 1,2-PG (87 %) with 31 % conversions, after 10 h of reaction using 0.5 MPa H2 [23]. Hao et al. modified a γ-Al2O3 support with tungstosilicic acid (H4SiW12O40) and improved the reducibility of Cu particles on the support, in turn increasing the acidity of the catalyst without promoting side reactions. The Cu-H4SiW12O40/γ-Al2O3 catalyst showed 90 % glycerol conversions with 89 % selectivity to 1,2-PG at 240 °C and 6 MPa H2 employing space velocities of 0.9 h−1 in a continuous flow reactor [24]. Cai et al. prepared Co-Al catalysts using the coprecipitation method, and modified it with H4SiW12O40 which made it possible to increase the conversion level with respect to Co-Al due to a higher dispersion of the Co particles. The Co-Al-H4SiW12O40 catalyst showed glycerol conversions of 76 % with 60 % selectivity to 1,2-PG at 230 °C and 3.5 MPa H2 using space velocities of 2.6 h−1 in a continuous flow reactor [25]. With respect to obtaining 1,3-PG, the use of H4SiW12O40 proved to be effective, either by addition to the reaction medium in the presence of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [26], or by modification of supports such as SiO2 [27], ZrO2 [28,29], Al2O3 [30] and ordered mesoporous Al2O3 (m-Al2O3) [31]. The results indicated that the modification of these supports with the heteropolyacid enhances the dispersion of Pt and confers the appropriate acidity for the formation of the intermediate in the production of 1,3-PG. As regards to 1-POH production, Zhu et al. employed Pt catalysts supported on H4SiW12O40-modified ZrO2 and evaluated them at 200 °C and 5 MPa H2 using 10 wt% aqueous glycerol solutions and space velocities of 0.045 h−1 in a continuous flow reactor. The results showed complete conversion of glycerol with 80 % joint selectivity to 1-POH and 2-propanol, and were attributed to good balance between acid sites and surface-active species for hydrogenation [32]. Based on the previously reported, in this work we prepared Pt catalysts using a mesoporous SiO2 support modified by inclusion of tungstophosphoric and tungstosilicic acid (TPA and TSA respectively) and evaluated them in the hydrogenolysis reaction of glycerol to obtain 1,3-PG and 1-POH in liquid phase. The objective is to provide a systematic comparison between two different Keggin-type heteropolyacids (TPA and TSA) immobilized in a hybrid silica matrix combined with Pt nanoparticles to be effective as bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts in glycerol hydrogenolysis. To the best of our knowledge, TSA has been scarcely explored in this reaction and never in direct comparison with TPA under identical synthesis and reaction conditions. From the characterization of the samples, the aim is to identify the catalytically active tungsten species present on the surface of the hybrid catalysts and correlate the acid and textural properties with the results of activity, selectivity and stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the support The silica (SiO2) support was prepared by the sol-gel based method using tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Sigma-Aldrich) as the precursor alkoxide and the triblock copolymer P123 (Poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol), PEO20PPO70PEO20, Sigma-Aldrich) as the template for mesopore formation. First, 4 g of P123 was dissolved in 103 ml of 2 N HCl aqueous solution and 30 g of distilled water in a conical flask. The suspension was stirred at 60 °C, when the solution became homogeneous 19.8 ml of TEOS was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 90 °C for 44 h. The solid formed was filtered and washed with distilled water. The P123 template was removed by heat treatment at 500 °C for 2 h. 2.2 Preparation of the supports modified with heteropolyacids Supports modified with tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) and tungstosilicic acid (TSA) were prepared from SiO2 by incorporating these heteropolyacids during silica synthesis. For a typical synthesis, P123, HCl and H2O were stirred in a conical flask as previously described. The required mass of TPA or TSA was dissolved in a 50 %v/v water-ethanol solution and added together with TEOS, to the mixture of P123, HCl and H2O and stirred at 90 °C for 44 h. The solid formed was filtered, washed with distilled water and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h. The supports obtained were named SiO2-TPA (x) and SiO2-TSA (x), where x is the percentage content of incorporated heteropolyacid (20, 30 or 40 wt%). 2.3 Catalyst preparation The Pt/SiO2-TPA (x) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (x) catalysts were prepared from the modified supports using the incipient wet impregnation method. Hexachloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6) was used as precursor in order to reach 2 wt% Pt content in the final catalysts. Distilled water was used as solvent to impregnate the supports. Once impregnated, the catalysts were dried at 105 °C for 12 h and calcined in a muffle at 300 °C for 90 min. 2.4 Characterization of support and catalysts The W content in the supports and the Pt content present in the catalysts were determined by atomic absorption spectrometry. To reduce interferences that could affect the analysis and convert the metals associated with particulate matter into a form suitable for determination—typically the free metal—the samples were digested in an oxidizing acidic medium. The appropriate amount of sample was transferred into a beaker, followed by the addition of 10 ml of a 3:1 mixture of HNO₃:HCl. The solution was heated at 80 °C on a heating mantle under a fume hood, with the beaker covered by a watch glass to minimize evaporation and splashing. After 2 h of digestion, the procedure was repeated as necessary until complete dissolution of the sample was achieved. The resulting solution was allowed to cool and then quantitatively transferred to a 50 ml volumetric flask and diluted to volume with Milli-Q water. A blank was prepared following the same procedure, using Milli-Q water. The equipment used was a single channel, dual beam IL Model 457 (Instrumentation Laboratory Inc). The light sources were hollow monocathode lamps. The calibration curve method was used with standards prepared in the laboratory. For the textural analysis of the supports and catalysts, adsorption and desorption measurements were carried out using N2 as a probe molecule. Surface area measurements were carried out using the Brunauer- Emmett and Teller (BET) multipoint method using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 equipment. Prior to analysis, the samples were vacuum degassed in one step at 100 °C and 30 μm Hg for 12 h. Textural characterization involved the determination of the specific surface area (SBET), the specific surface area of micropores (Smicro) and the average pore diameter (dp). The 31P MAS NMR experiments were performed in a Bruker MSL-300 equipment using 5 m pulses, a repetition time of 3 s, and working at a frequency of 121.496 MHz, at room temperature, the resolution being 3.052 Hz per point. A 5 mm diameter and 10 mm high sample holder was used, the spin rate was 2.1 kHz. Several hundred pulse responses were collected. Phosphoric acid 85 % was employed as external reference. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) measurements were carried out using a Bruker IFS 66 FT-IT infrared spectrophotometer. In each test, the sample was prepared as pellets with an approximate concentration of 1 wt% in KBr. The measurement range was 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 2 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out using a TA Instruments model Q50 thermobalance coupled to a Thermo Scientific Nicolet is10 infrared spectrometer, DTGS detector and KBr windows. The tests were performed from room temperature up to 600 °C using a ramp of 20 °C min−1 in N2 flow with a flow rate of 100 ml min−1. The released gases were collected and analyzed in-situ by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) in the range 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 8 cm−1. X-ray diffractograms (XRD) were obtained using a Bruker D8 Advance A25 powder diffractometer using Cu radiation (Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å, intensity = 30 mA and voltage = 40 kV). The diffractograms were collected in the range 2θ = 5°- 80°. The identification of crystalline phases was carried out based on literature data. The Scherrer equation (Eq. 1) was employed to estimate the average crystallite (dXRD). (1) d XRD = K . λ B . cos ( θ ) where K = 0.89, λ = 0.15418 nm, B (rad) is the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the most intense peak of the crystalline phase, and θ (rad) is the angle measured at the center of the peak. The total number of acid sites and their acid strength were estimated from the potentiometric titration curve, obtained using a Metrohm 794 Basic Titrino with a double junction electrode. In each assay, 50 mg of sample was suspended in 45 ml of acetonitrile (Cicarelli) and stirred for 1 h prior to analysis. The suspension was then titrated with a 0.05 N solution of n-butylamine (Carlo Erba) in acetonitrile. Particle size and morphology were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using an ESEM FEI Quanta 250 microscope. For sample preparation, a small amount of the synthetized material was placed on a carbon ribbon and coated with gold by sputtering. The elemental chemical composition was determined by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) using an Oxford SDD X-Act detector with AZTecOne software attached to the ESEM FEI Quanta 250. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired on a JEOL JEM-2100 Plus TEM instrument equipped with an Oxford X-MAX 65 T EDS and operated at 200 kV. The observations were performed in HRTEM and HAADF mode, for which the powder samples were homogeneously dispersed in 2-propanol by sonication. Then, drops of the resulting suspension were deposited on a Cu TEM grid (Lacey Carbon Film 300 mesh, Electron Microscopy Science), which were dried prior to analysis. Particle size was estimated considering spherical particles from the equation for volume-area diameter (Eq. 2). (2) d va ( nm ) = ∑ n i . d i 3 ∑ n i . d i 2 Histograms were made from the TEM micrographs using the bright field technique, counting approximately 20 particles per image for a total of 15 images per sample. From the volume-area diameter, the dispersion (D) of the Pt metal particles was estimated using Brunelle's approximation (Eq. 3). (3) D ( % ) = 108 d va X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using a nonmonochromatic Mg Kα source (XR50, Specs GmbH) and a hemispherical electron energy analyzer (PHOIBOS 100, Specs GmbH) operating in fixed transmission analysis mode with pass energies of 40 and 20 eV. A two-point calibration of the energy scale was performed using gold (Au 4 f7/2, binding energy BE = 84.00 eV) and copper (Cu 2p3/2, BE = 932.67 eV) samples cleaned with a sputtering ion gun. Adventitious carbon (component C 1 s at 284.8 eV) was used as a charging reference. The pressure during the measurements was typically in the range of 10−7 Pa at ambient temperature. XPS data were analyzed using CASA-xps v2.2.99 software, employing a Shirley-type background line. Quantification analysis based on peak areas and the relative sensitivity factor was employed. The quantification method assumes no geometry preference by analytes and use the atomic percentage (% At), considering all the signals detected for all the elements. The analysis is typically performed at a depth equivalent to three times the electron attenuation length. Powder of fresh and used Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) samples was spread on vacuum carbon tape (SPE supplies) and analysis was carried out at a takeoff angle of 90°. 2.5 Catalytic activity tests The tests were carried out in a high-pressure batch reactor constructed of stainless-steel BR-100 (Berghof, Eningen, Germany) with a capacity of 100 ml. In a typical experiment, a 5 wt% aqueous solution of analytical glycerol (99.99 wt%, Cicarelli) was introduced into the reactor together with the catalyst previously reduced ex-situ in H2 flow (50 ml min−1) at 500 °C for 90 min. The glycerol/catalyst mass ratio was 0.945 in all tests. After loading of the reagents and catalyst, the reactor was closed and purged several times with N2 to remove the air contained inside. It was then purged several times with H2 to remove the remaining N2 and pressurized with H2 up to 2 MPa. Afterwards, the reactor was heated (10 °C min −1) to the desired temperature (180–220 °C) and when autogenous pressure reached the corresponding value for each temperature (4.0–4.5 MPa), the stirring began. In all cases, glycerol hydrogenolysis takes place in the liquid phase in the presence of the solid catalyst and the gaseous hydrogen, so a liquid-solid-gas reaction must be considered. In these cases, the absence of internal and external mass and heat transfer resistances must be ensured to perform valid catalytic tests. As the reactor is occupied with dilute glycerol solutions (5 wt%) and high-pressure hydrogen, the gas–liquid interphase is saturated with H2 and the gas phase mass transfer resistance can be considered negligible. This also led to an insignificant variation in autogenous pressure. The absence of external mass transfer was evaluated by varying the stirring speed between 500 rpm and 1000 rpm, verifying that there was no resistance above 750 rpm. Thus, all experiments were performed with a stirring speed of 1000 rpm. In order to ensure the absence of internal mass transfer resistances, the catalyst was ground into a fine powder. All these conditions lead to consider heat transfer resistances negligible ensuring a uniform temperature within the reactor. Identification and quantification of the reaction products was carried out by gas chromatography using a Shimadzu GCMS QP5050A equipped with a PE-Elite-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.5 µm) (Perkin Elmer), and FID-MS detectors. The percentage conversion of glycerol (X) was calculated according to Eq. 4. (4) X ( % ) = moles of consumed glycerol initial moles of glycerol . 100 % The selectivity towards product i (Si) was determined according to Eq. 5. (5) S i ( % ) = moles of product i total moles of products . 100 % The carbon balance (C) was calculated according to Eq. 6. (6) C ( % ) = total moles of carbon in products 3 . initial moles of glycerol . 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the supports Table 1 shows the results of the textural characterization and acidic properties of the SiO2 and the SiO2-TPA and SiO2-TSA modified supports. According to Table 1 results, the SiO2 support presents a specific surface area (SBET) of 836 m2 g−1 and a micropore surface area (Smicro) of 414 m2 g−1, suggesting a micro-mesoporous nature. The isotherms of the support, shown in Supplementary Information (Figure S1) is of type IV according to the IUPAC classification, indicating that nitrogen adsorption occurs in multilayers [33]. In addition, the isotherm presents a H2-type hysteresis loop at relative pressures (P/Po) ranging from 0.45 to 0.98, confirming the micro-mesoporous characteristic [34]. On the other hand, the TPA- and TSA-modified supports present significantly lower specific surface area values, due to the incorporation of the heteropolyacids with concentrations of 20, 30 and 40 wt% in the silica structure. In addition, a decrease in the SBET/Smicro specific surface area ratio is observed, which may be due to a decrease in the level of cross-linking when the concentration of the heteropolyacid increases. A similar behavior was reported in the literature for the specific surface area of mesoporous TiO2 obtained by the sol-gel process [35,36]. The strength and number of acid sites present on the supports were determined using the potentiometric titration technique with n-butylamine using acetonitrile as solvent. Information about this technique can be found in the Supplementary Information (S2) [37]. Potentiometric titration curves for the supports are also presented in Supplementary Information (Figure S2). Table 1 indicates that SiO2 exhibits strong sites (Ei = 23 mV), which could be due to the presence of silanol groups (Si-OH) acting as Lewis’s acid sites, as previously reported [38]. Modification of the SiO2 support with TPA and TSA generates changes in the acidic strength and total number of sites. The SiO2-TPA(x) supports exhibit very strong acid sites (692 mV < Ei < 812 mV) as do the SiO2-TSA(x) supports (775 mV < Ei < 784 mV), and in both cases there is an increase in the total number of sites as the total heteropolyacid content in the catalyst increases. Fig. 1 shows the FT-IR spectra of the TPA and the SiO2 and SiO2-TPA supports. The FT-IR spectrum of SiO2 shows the typical bands of silica ( Table 2) and does not show any of the characteristic bands of P123 used as a template. For the SiO2-TPA (20), SiO2-TPA (30) and SiO2-TPA (40) supports, the FT-IR spectra reveal the presence of the P-Oa, WOd and W-Ob-W bands of TPA (Table 2) which overlap with those of the support [39]. The intensity of the bands increases with increasing TPA content incorporated during support synthesis [40,41]. A similar analysis was carried out for SiO2-TSA (40) in a previous work [42]. In this case, the spectrum shows bands at 1019, 982, 926, 884, 782 and 540 cm−1 characteristics of TSA, which overlap the bands characteristic of silica. The first band has no assignment, while the others correspond to the stretching vibrations W-Od, Si-Oa, W-Ob-W and W-Oc-W and to the bending vibrations Oa-Si-Oa + W-O-W, respectively. The subscripts indicate: oxygen linking the W and the heteroatom (a) corner-sharing oxygen, (b) edge-sharing oxygen, (c) belonging to the octahedral WO6, and (d) terminal oxygen. The FT-IR results suggest that the incorporation of TPA and TSA during the synthesis of SiO2, followed by its thermal treatment, is a suitable method to obtain a heteropolyacid-silica composite that keeps the Keggin structure intact. The 31P magic angle spinning-nuclear magnetic resonance spectra of SiO2-TPA (20), SiO2-TPA (30), and SiO2-TPA (40) samples ( Fig. 2(a), (b), and (c), respectively) display a line at −14.8 ppm, which was attributed to [HXPW12O40](3-X)− species [43]. Furthermore, the 31P NMR spectrum of SiO2-TPA (40) sample shows a second and less intense line at −15.0 ppm ascribed to the [PW12O40]3− Keggin anion [44] interacting with H+(H2O)2 species [45,46]. In the case of hydrated TPA (H3PW12O40.6H2O) this line appears at −15.3 ppm. The downfield shift observed, compared to that of the TPA, was due to the electrostatic interaction between the anions and the Si-OH2 + groups present in SiO2-TPA samples. A similar behavior was suggested for the interaction of TPA with zirconia and titania [43]. 3.2 Catalyst characterization Once the modified supports were prepared, they were impregnated with H2PtCl6 to obtain a nominal content of 2 ± 0.2 wt% of Pt in the final catalysts. By AAS it was determined that in all cases the Pt content was close to the nominal, with no differences between the prepared catalysts. Once impregnated, the catalysts were dried in an oven at 105 °C for 12 h and calcined at 300 °C in sealed air for 90 min. Fig. 3 shows the thermograms of the Pt/SiO2, Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) catalysts once calcined. For the three catalysts, a weight loss in the range of 5–10 % is observed before 100 °C. The derivative analysis shows a peak approximately between 65 and 79 °C, which would indicate the desorption of water molecules adsorbed on the surface of the catalysts. This is consistent with the reported thermogravimetric analyzes of TPA and TSA, which reveal weight loss (associated with the release of physiosorbed water molecules) below 200 ºC [47]. No peaks corresponding to the decomposition of the Pt precursor are observed, indicating that it was reached during the calcination stage. These results are in accordance with those reported by Li et al. who determined that H2PtCl6 decomposes into PtCl4 at 150 °C, then forming PtCl2 at 200 °C and finally Pt at 270 °C [48]. Table 3 shows the results of the textural and physicochemical characterization of the catalysts reduced in H2 flow at 300 °C. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms shown in Supplementary Information (Figure S3), maintain typology IV with H2 hysteresis loops, indicating that the Pt catalysts preserve the micro and mesoporous characteristics of the supports. The results in Table 3 indicate that Pt catalysts present lower specific surface areas and total pore volumes than the supports by which were prepared, indicating that the presence of Pt clogs part of the pores of the support. Regarding the acidic properties, the potentiometric titration curves of the catalysts are shown in Supplementary Information (Figure S4). The results in Table 3 indicate that, in all cases, the incorporation of Pt to the modified supports increases the total number of sites and their acidic strength. In particular, the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts present NS values in the range 0.37–0.59 mmol g−1, while the Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts present a greater total number of sites, in the range 0.54–0.68 mmol g−1. Although both series of catalysts present very strong acid sites, those based on TPA have greater acid strength (Ei = 622–783 mV) than those based on TSA (Ei = 200–277 mV). These results are in agreement with the fact that TPA displays higher acid strength than TSA. Fig. 4 shows the X-ray diffractograms (XRD) of the catalysts. Fig. 4 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts. For all samples, a very broad peak in the 2θ range of 15°–30° is observed, which is characteristic of amorphous silica. Additionally, all diffractograms exhibit diffraction peaks at 2θ = 39.8°, 46.2°, and 67.5°, corresponding to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), and (2 2 0) planes of the face-centered cubic (fcc) structure of metallic platinum (JCPDS No. 04–0802). The moderate broadening of these peaks indicates that the Pt particles are nanometric and relatively well dispersed on the silica support. The full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the Pt (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) reflections were used to estimate crystallite sizes using the Scherrer equation. For Pt/SiO2 the crystallite size is about 9.5 nm, but decrease in the modified supports, yielding average values between 3.4 and 3.0 nm for TPA contents between 20 and 40 wt% and between 3.1 and 2.2 nm for TSA contents between 20 and 40 wt%. This would indicate that Pt dispersion is improved at high contents of heteropolyacid in the SiO2 support. Regarding the heteropolyacid phases, for Pt/SiO₂-TPA catalysts, reflections assigned to H₃PW₁₂O₄₀·6H₂O (JCPDS No. 98–009–2218) become noticeable only at the highest loading (40 wt%), with peaks at 2θ = 25.3° (2 2 2), 34.5° (2 3 3), 53.2° (0 5 5), and 59.8° (2 3 7). In contrast, for Pt/SiO₂-TSA catalysts, reflections corresponding to bulk H₄SiW₁₂O₄₀·6H₂O (JCPDS No. 01–0559) are evident already at 30 wt% and become more intense at 40 wt%, with sharp and intense peaks at 2θ = 23.2° (3 1 0), 24.1° (2 2 2), 33.4° (3 3 2), 41.4° (4 4 0), 54.3° (6 4 0), and 59.8° (6 5 1). For these samples, crystallites sizes calculated based on the Scheerer equation using the reflection at 33.4° are of about 8.8 and 8.4 nm respectively. This would indicate that a small amount of TSA is present on the SiO2 support as segregated crystallites, suggesting a lower dispersion in these cases. Fig. 5 shows the SEM micrographs for the Pt/SiO₂-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO₂-TSA (40) catalysts, coupled with the energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) results. The EDX maps, obtained at low magnification, suggest that both Pt and W are homogeneously distributed within the silica matrix at the micrometer scale. From the EDS spectra for these catalysts (Figure S5) it was possible to calculate the Pt/Si, W/Si and HPA/SiO2 elemental molar ratios, where HPA represents the heteropolyacid (TPA or TSA); these results are shown in Supplementary Information (Table S6). They indicate that both catalysts have a similar Pt/Si molar ratio (∼0.01), which allows us to infer a similar distribution of Pt atoms on the silica. A similar effect is observed for the W/Si ratio (∼0.10) and the HPA/SiO2 ratio (∼0.008) in both catalysts, which indicates a similar distribution of the heteropolyacid on the support. Fig. 6 shows the micrographs obtained by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) for the catalysts and their corresponding frequency histograms. The diameters obtained from the volume-area relationship for each of the samples and their corresponding metallic dispersion values are shown in Table 3. As can be seen, Pt/SiO2 has a dva = 2.9 nm which corresponds to a metallic dispersion of 37.2 %, while the Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts have smaller particle sizes. For Pt/SiO2-TPA the average particle sizes range from 2.9 nm to 1.9 nm for TPA contents increasing from 20 % to 40 %, while in the case of Pt/SiO2-TSA, the average particle sizes they go from 2.6 nm to 1.5 nm for an increase in TSA content from 20 % to 40 %. These results would indicate that the modification of SiO2 with TPA and TSA improves the dispersion of Pt metallic particles in the support. For all samples, high-resolution TEM images were taken, with the aim of determining the morphology of the metal particles and the distance between planes of the Pt crystalline lattice; which proved viable in particles of at least 5 nm or larger. As an example, Fig. 7 shows the results for Pt/SiO2, where the presence of spherical, elliptical and irregularly shaped particles is observed. These particles are consistent with the Pt crystal lattice, identifying values of distances between planes of 0.135 nm, 0.195 nm and 0.225 nm, corresponding to the (2 2 0), (2 0 0) and (1 1 1) planes of the cubic phase of metallic Pt respectively. These results agree with those obtained from the X-ray diffractograms (JCPDS 04–0802). 3.3 Activity tests The activity tests were carried out in the range 180–220°C and 2 MPa of H2 for 2 h of reaction, using 5 wt% glycerol solutions and glycerol/catalyst mass ratios (mgly/mc) = 0.95. The reason for using diluted solutions and a low mgly/mc ratio is based on the results obtained by Arundhathi et al., who used Pt/WOx/AlOOH catalysts and obtained complete conversion of glycerol with the highest selectivity to 1,3-PG reported to date (∼66 %) [49]. Fig. 8 shows the conversions obtained with the Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts as a function of temperature and the heteropolyacid content. From Fig. 8, it is observed that the Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts are active in the hydrogenolysis reaction, and their activity level increases as the temperature and the heteropolyacid content in the catalyst increase. It is also possible to observe that, at each thermal level, the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts are more active than the Pt/SiO2-TSA. Since both are prepared with the same method, using the same metal precursor and nominal Pt content, the differences would be assigned to the nature of the supports modified with TPA and TSA. In both cases, the acidity comes from the groups [HXPW12O40](3−X)− and [HXSiW12O40](4−X)− (TPA and TSA respectively) interacting with the Si-OH2 + groups present in the silica, whose presence was revealed by FT-IR and 31P MAS NMR. According to the results obtained by potentiometric titration, the Pt/SiO2-TPA series presents a slightly lower number of acid sites than the Pt/SiO2-TSA series, a number that increases as the heteropolyacid content in the catalysts increases. However, the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts have a greater acid strength, which would be responsible for the increase in activity observed in Fig. 8. Fig. 9 shows the results of the natural logarithm of the turnover frequency (TOF) based on glycerol consumption versus the inverse of the absolute temperature (1/T) for the series of Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts in the thermal range 180–220 °C. The selected temperature interval was limited by the low activity observed below 180 °C and the risk of undesirable decomposition reactions above 220 °C. Additionally, while complementary experiments at shorter reaction times (30 min and 1 h) yielded comparable TOF values to those obtained at 2 h, lower conversions under those conditions led to higher uncertainty in rate estimation. For this reason, a reaction time of 2 h was selected to improve the reliability of the calculated rates. The data were fitted using an Arrhenius-type expression to estimate apparent and global activation energies, which are reported in Table 4. As can be seen, the activation energies for the Pt/SiO2-TSA and Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts are in the range 76–93 kJ mol−1. In this range, similar results were obtained using Pt/Fe3O4 (61.1 kJ mol−1) [50] and Pt/C (63.3 kJ mol−1) [51] and Pd-Cu/Mg5.6-xAl2O8.6-X (77.1 kJ mol−1) [52]. Other systems based on noble metals such as Rh/C (98.0 kJ mol−1) [53], Co-Pd-Re/C (98.0 kJ mol−1) [54] and Ru-Re/SiO2 (107.8 kJ mol−1) [55] showed slightly higher activation energies. Regarding the reaction products, the results showed a low conversion to gases (< 3 %) with the presence of CH4 and CO2. The reaction products identified and quantified in the liquid phase were: C1: methanol (MeOH), C2: ethanol (EtOH), ethylene glycol (EG), C3: acetone (AcO), 1-propanol (1-POH), 1.2 -propylene glycol (1,2-PG) and 1,3-propylene glycol (1,3-PG). In all cases the carbon balance was ∼ 98 %. Fig. 10 shows the distribution of liquid products as a function of temperature for the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts. As can be seen from Fig. 10, the selectivity to C1 and C2 is considerably low in the thermal range studied (180–220 °C) regardless of their TPA content. These results are notable, since other systems based on noble metals such as Ru and Pt have shown a certain tendency to break C-C bonds [56,57]. With respect to the rest of the liquid products, the catalysts are selective towards the formation of C3 products, with 1-POH, 1,3-PG, and 1,2-PG being the main products, which demonstrates the natural selective of these catalysts towards C-O cleavage reactions. Looking at Fig. 10 (a), (b) and (c), it is possible to notice that the selectivity to 1,2-PG is lower than the selectivity to 1-POH and 1,3-PG in all cases. At low temperature, the selectivity to 1,3-PG is greater than the selectivity to 1-POH, while as the temperature increases, the trend reverses. This would indicate that temperature favors the conversion of 1,3-PG to 1-POH, as we have recently reported in a comprehensive review [12]. Regarding the presence of the heteropolyacid, it is observed that as the TPA content increases, there is an increase in selectivity to 1-POH with a decrease in selectivity to 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG, which could be due to excessive hydrogenolysis due to the presence of a greater number of acid sites. The hydrogenolysis of glycerol is carried out through a first stage that involves C-O bond breaking reactions to form acetol (AcOH) and 3-hydroxypropionaldehyde (3-HPA), and then these intermediates are hydrogenated to form 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG respectively. The C-O bond cleavage stages often involve the acid sites of the support, while the hydrogenation steps involve the presence of the metallic sites. If the hydrogenolysis process continues, these glycols can lead to the formation of 1-POH, through consecutive reactions involving C-O and hydrogenation reactions. In addition, there are secondary C-C bond breaking reactions that form EG and MeOH and hydrodeoxygenation reactions that form EtOH and AcO [58–60]. The complex set of reactions is shown in Scheme 1. The results of Fig. 10 would indicate that the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts follow the reaction route shown in Scheme 1, favoring the formation of 1-POH from the glycols 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG. Fig. 11 shows the distribution of liquid products as a function of temperature for the Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts. The results of Fig. 11 indicate that the formation of C1 and C2 compounds is also not significant in the series of Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts, with the C3 products being the majority, mainly 1-POH, 1,3-PG and 1,2-PG. As for the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts, a trend towards the formation of 1-POH is observed with increasing temperature, regardless of the TSA content in the catalysts. Furthermore, the thermal increase favors the formation of terminal alcohols such as MeOH and EtOH in these catalysts. Regarding the selectivity of the triplet 1-POH, 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG, it is a function of the TSA content according to the operating temperature. In all cases, an increase in TSA content leads to an increase in selectivity to 1-POH, together with a decrease in selectivity to glycols. At 180 °C, the increase in selectivity to 1-POH is due to a decrease in selectivity to 1,2-PG, since 1,3-PG increases its selectivity as a function of TSA content. The same happens at 200 °C. This would indicate that up to that thermal level the Pt/SiO2-TSA series forms 1-POH at the expense of 1,2-PG. With the increase in temperature to 220 °C, the formation is favored from a consumption of 1,3-PG, with the selectivity to 1,2-PG remaining practically unchanged. To compare the selectivity of both series of catalysts, Figs. 10 (b) and 11 (b) can be contrasted, which show the distribution of liquid products at similar conversion values in the range 10–15 % at 200 °C and 2 MPa (initial pressure) of H2, using 5 wt% glycerol solutions and glycerol/catalyst mass ratios (mgly/mc) = 0.95. The results in Fig. 10 (b) show that the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts follow the selectivity trend: 1-POH > 1,3-PG > 1,2-PG. In this sense, the selectivity to 1,3-PG decreases from 37 % to 34 % and that of 1,2-PG from 28 % to 5 % as the selectivity to 1-POH increases from 19 % to 54 %, when the TPA content in the catalyst increases from 0 % to 40 %. These results would indicate that 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG are intermediates in the formation of 1-POH, and the generation of this product would depend on the content of acid sites. Fig. 11 (b), meanwhile, shows that the Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts reverse the order of selectivity towards the main products: 1,3-PG > 1-POH > 1,2-PG. It is observed that the selectivity to 1-POH increases from 19 % to 42 % as the selectivity to 1,2-PG decreases from 28 % to 5 % for an increase in TSA content from 0 % to 40 %. Since the selectivity to 1,3-PG (∼45 %) remains practically unchanged with increasing TSA content, 1,2-PG would be the only intermediate in the formation of 1-POH. In this sense, Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts are comparatively more selective to 1,3-PG than Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts. Zhu et al. used Pt-TSA/SiO2 and Pt-TPA/SiO2 catalysts at 180 °C and 5 MPa of H2 in a continuous flow reactor (WHSV = 0.09 h−1). Their results showed glycerol conversions of ∼25 % for both catalysts with 48 % and 32 % selectivity values to 1,3-PG respectively [29]. Pt/TSA-Al2O3 catalysts showed glycerol conversions of 45 % with 10 % selectivity to 1,3-PG at 240 °C and 6 MPa of H2, after 8 h of reaction using a mgly/mc ratio = 25 [30]. Gu et al. prepared a Pt/TSA-Al2O3 catalyst and tested it at 200 °C and 4 MPa of H2, using a lower mgly/mc ratio = 0.9 but reaction times of 15 h, obtaining glycerol conversions of 60 % with 33 % selectivity to 1,3-PG [31]. The difference in selectivity to 1,3-PG for both works could be due to the thermal level used. In order to correlate the characterization results with the activity results, Fig. 12 presents the functionality of the glycerol conversion and the selectivity to C3 products in terms of the density of acid sites, calculated based on the number of sites acids obtained by potentiometric titration and the specific surface area calculated with the BET model. As can be seen, for both series of catalysts, the glycerol conversion increases linearly with the density of the acid sites (Fig. 12 a and b), indicating that the first C-O bond cleavage from glycerol to form AcOH and 3-HPA as intermediates depends on the acid sites of the support, as it was suggested in Scheme 1. At the same time, a linear decrease in the selection of glycols, 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG (Fig. 12 c and d) and a linear increase in the selection of 1-POH (Fig. 12 e and f) is observed. These results confirm that the formation of 1-POH occurs through 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG as intermediates though acid sites and suggest that the formation of C3 products is sensitive to the distribution of surface chemical species on the catalysts. Similar correlations were made for the performance at 1,3-PG where the surface concentration of acid sites was provided by heteropolyacids, such as Pt-H4SiW12O40/ZrO2 [28], Pt-H3PW12O40-ZrO2 [29] and Pt-H3PMo12O40/ZrO2 [29]. With respect to metallic phase, different particle sizes distributions were obtained from the same nominal content of Pt (2 wt%) in the Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA samples, as the presence of TPA and TSA affects the metal dispersion. With the aim to elucidate the effect of the metallic phase in the reaction mechanism, conversion and selectivity values were correlated in function of the average particle size (dva) of Pt for all catalysts ( Fig. 13). As can be seen from Fig. 13 (a) and (b), conversion decreases with the increment of the dva, indicating that small particles produce the highest levels of glycerol consumption. Similar results have been reported for catalysts based on Ru, Pt and Pd. Miyazawa et al. prepared Ru/C catalysts employing Ru(NO)(NO3)3 as a precursor, obtaining the highest glycerol conversion and selectivity to 1,2-PG due to the generation of Ru particles with sizes smaller than 2 nm [59]. Balaraju et al. employed the deposition–precipitation method to prepare Ru/TiO2 catalysts and obtained small size metal particles (dva ∼1–3 nm) due to the reduction in Ru(OH)3 species generated during the catalyst preparation process; with the use of the incipient moisture impregnation method, the formation of larger Ru particles (dva ∼ 10 nm) led to lower activity levels [61]. Oberhauser et al. prepared Pt/C catalysts by the vapor phase metal deposition method using different supports and obtained high metal dispersion with particle sizes between 1.3 nm and 2.5 nm, depending on the specific surface area of the support; these catalysts led to high levels of activity and stability [62]. Pd/Fe2O3 [63], PdO/CoO [63], Pd/Co3O4 [64], and Pd/Fe3O4 [64] catalysts were prepared by coprecipitation and showed higher levels of activity than those prepared by impregnation due to higher dispersions of the metal phase. With respect to selectivity towards the C3 products, it follows a different tendency depending on the liquid product. In this sense, 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG are favored over larger particles (Fig. 13 (c) and (d)), while selectivity to 1-POH is favored over small particles (Fig. 13 (e) and (f)). These results are in agreement with those presented in Fig. 12, where conversion and selectivity to 1-POH increases with the acid sites density and selectivity to glycols follow the opposite tendency. As it was mentioned previously, dispersion is favored when increasing the heteropolyacid content in the SiO2 support, so the highest levels of conversion and selectivity to 1-POH should be obtained with small metallic particles, while the obtention of 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG requires lower values of acid sites density, indicating that the formation of glycols would be favored over larger metallic particles. The fact that conversion and selectivity to C3 products are affected by particle size would indicate that Pt plays a catalytic role in glycerol hydrogenolysis mechanism. As glycerol conversion proceeds though a first stage of C-O bond cleavage and it depends on the average particle size, the presence of Pt in the form of small particles would favor the formation of AcOH and 3-HPA (Scheme 1), in the presence of high acid sites density (Fig. 12 (a) and (b)). Dasari et al. carried out screening studies of Pt/C catalysts and determined that these systems are comparatively less active than Ru/C catalysts but shows a higher selectivity to 1,2-PG due to the intrinsic ability of Pt to promote the breaking of C-O bonds [58]. This would explain the ability of Pt to participate in the first stages of glycerol conversion. Following the reaction pathways, the hydrogenation of these intermediates produces 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG respectively, whose step would be favored over larger Pt particles and low acid sites density (Fig. 12 (c) and (d)). Finally, the formation of 1-POH involves a C-O cleavage reaction and a hydrogenation step, which would be favored over small Pt particles and high acid sites density (Fig. 12 (e) and (f)). The results here obtained indicate that glycerol hydrogenolysis over Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts is affected by the presence of Pt and its metal dispersion. To fix some insights about the role of Pt, SiO2 and the heteropolyacids, some references reactions have been carried out employing SiO2, SiO2-TPA (40), SiO2-TSA (40), Pt/SiO2, Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) catalysts. The results are presented in Table 5. As can be seen, the SiO2 support shows little glycerol conversion, with the presence of MeOH and EtOH due to C-C bond cleavage reactions, and AcOH, 1,2-PG and 1,3-PG due to C-O bond cleavage and hydrogenation reactions. When Pt is added to this support, glycerol conversion is enhanced and the main liquid products results: 1,2-PG, 1,3-PG and 1-POH, with almost suppression of C-C bond cleavage due to the low selectivity to MeOH, EtOH and EG. This would confirm the role of Pt in improving the C-O bond cleavage. Modified supports, on the other hand, exhibit higher glycerol conversion than SiO2, being the SiO2-TSA(40) more active than SiO2-TPA(40). This demonstrates that the inclusion of heteropolyacids enhances catalytic activity of the SiO2 support. For both supports, 1,2-PG, 1,3-PG, AcO and AcOH are the main liquid products. The presence of AcO and AcOH would indicate the ability of the materials to dehydrate and form CO species. As the metallic phase is absence in these supports, glycerol dehydrates to AcOH, which cannot be hydrogenated to 1,2-PG and forms AcO by dehydration. These results could confirm the intrinsic activity of these supports for glycerol dehydration and so to participate in the first stages of glycerol conversion. The addition of Pt to these supports enhances glycerol conversion with respect to the modified supports, suppresses the formation of AcO and improves the formation of 1,3-PG and 1-POH. Based on the above, the complex system of Pt, SiO2 and the inclusion of TPA/TSA is required to reach high activity and selectivity to the desired products.” 3.4 Reuse and stability tests In order to study the reusability of the catalysts, their activity was evaluated in successive reaction cycles of 2 h each at 220 °C and 2 MPa of H2. After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration, the solids were washed with distilled water and dried in an oven at 105 °C for 24 h. The next cycle was carried out without practicing any additional treatment. Fig. 14 shows the results obtained using the most active catalysts, Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40). Fig. 14 (a) indicates that during the first three reaction cycles the Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) catalyst maintains the activity in the 57–49 % conversion range, while from the third cycle onwards the conversion experiences a decrease between 33 % (fourth use) and 16 % (fifth use). It is also observed that throughout the reaction cycles there is a modification in the selectivity values to C3: the selectivity to 1-POH decreases at the expense of an increase in the selectivity to glycols, 1,3-PG and 1,2 -PG. Particularly, the selectivity to 1,3-PG experiences an increase until the fourth reaction cycle and then decreases, giving rise to the formation of 1,2-PG, which shows competition between both glycols. For the case of Pt/SiO2-TSA (40), Fig. 14 (b) shows that the activity decreases by 18 % from the second use and is maintained throughout four reaction cycles, experiencing a decrease only in the fifth use. Regarding selectivity, a phenomenon similar to that obtained with Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) occurs, but much less pronounced. In order to understand the reasons for the deactivation, characterization tests were carried out on the samples used, Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40), after the fifth reaction use. To do this, after the last cycle, the samples were washed with distilled water and dried in an oven at 105 °C for 12 h. The results of the thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTG) and the FT-IR spectra of the gases evolved for both samples are presented in Fig. 15. The thermogravimetric analysis shown in Fig. 15 (a) shows mass losses of 10.5 % and 11.5 % for Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) respectively. For these samples, several decomposition events are observed at temperatures lower than 100 °C and a more defined event located approximately at 525 °C. The first would indicate the desorption of physisorbed molecules, such as water and CO2. The second event, on the other hand, could indicate the presence of coke or the desorption of chemisorbed molecules. The FT-IR spectra of the gases evolved during the thermogravimetric analysis for both samples are presented in Fig. 15 (b) and (c). In both cases, well-marked bands are observed in the range 3500–4000 cm−1 and 1500–2000 cm−1, which would correspond to -OH groups, and a small band between 2300 and 2400 cm−1 characteristic of CO2. These results allow us to rule out deactivation due to the presence of coke, but do not rule out the presence of chemisorbed glycerol molecules due to the existence of bands corresponding to hydroxyl groups. Table 3 shows a drop in the values of specific surface area and micropore volume in the used catalysts. The isotherms of both catalysts used are shown in Supplementary Information (Figure S7). These results would indicate a collapse of pores in the catalyst due to a sintering process of the support, probably due to the hydrothermal conditions of the reaction, as has been reported for commercial silica supports [65]. Fig. 4(c) shows the X-ray diffractograms for fresh and used Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) catalysts. With respect to the Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) samples, the presence of peaks associated with the heteropolyacid is observed in the fresh sample but not in the used sample. Besides, the presence of metallic Pt is not observed in the fresh sample, probably due to the dispersion provided by the presence of the heteropolyacid, while in the used sample the presence of the peaks is noticeable. These results would support the hypothesis that the heteropolyacid is lost by leaching in the liquid phase. In the case of the Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) catalysts, no differences are observed in terms of the presence of peaks associated with TSA and metallic Pt in the fresh and used samples, which would indicate the conservation of the crystalline structure. Fig. 6(h) and (i) show the TEM micrographs and particle size distributions for the catalysts used, Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40), respectively. In the case of used Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) sample, the presence of very small particles (∼1 nm) (not present in the fresh sample) is observed (Fig. 6(d)), which leads to a slight decrease in the average particle size, from 1.9 nm to 1.5 nm. In the case of Pt/SiO2-TSA (40), a distribution of particle sizes similar to that of the fresh sample is observed (Fig. 6(g)), but the presence of a higher content of Pt particles with sizes between 2.5 nm and 4 nm increases the average particle size from 1.5 nm to 1.7 nm. Regarding the acid-base properties, the results in Table 3 indicate a drop in the surface acidity and acid strength values of the sites, which could indicate a change in the surface chemical composition. With the aim to investigate the surface chemical changes, XPS tests were carried out on the fresh and used samples of the Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) catalysts. Table 6 shows the atomic percentages of all principals and distinguish regions on Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) fresh and used samples. As it can be seen from the table, the interfacial change rate of W4f between used and fresh samples is noteworthy. While the variation of W4f quantity at the interface in Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) is an increase of close to 5 %, for Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) this value is a depletion of more than 80 %. A similar proportion can be found in the W/Si ratio for both samples, but not in Pt/Si. These indicates a clear difference for interactions and chemical identity of W on both surfaces. On the other hand, the O/Si ratio changes little between the Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) used and the fresh samples. Fresh Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) data, depicted in Fig. 16 (a), show a main doublet with binding energies (BE) for 4f7/2 in 35.6 eV (W6+) very close to chemical shift of [W2O7]2- species and a little one with 4f7/2 in 34.2 eV (W5+) assigned to W2O5, also a fit in 41.5 eV assigned to W5p3/2 was necessary [66–68]. Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) used, depicted in Fig. 16 (b), show a different W4f composition. Two species of W6+, with BE 4f7/2 = 35.8 eV, close to [WO4]2- species [67,69] and 37.0 eV typical for WO3 [70] were found, W5p3/2 is not distinguished from background, because signal to noise ratio is higher than others recorded regions, mostly by the lower quantity of W in this sample. Fig. 16 (c) show the XPS spectra for Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) before reaction. Fresh sample is fitted with doublets with BE 4f7/2 in 33.9 eV most likely to kind [W2O6]2- than W2O5 species (or kind chemical environment with oxo bridges like W-O-W between W5+) [71]), 35.2 eV (W6+ in H4SiW12O40 [72]), 36.2 eV (W6+ assigned to complex species with chemical environment between [WO4]2- and [W2O7]2- like [W7O24]6- [73] and a broad peak in 41.2 eV correspond to W5p3/2 signals. With respect to Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) used sample, depicted in Fig. 16 (d), only two doublets by W4f, BE 4f7/2 in 34.5 eV like W2O5 [74] and 4f7/2 in 35.7 eV typical [WO4]2- species [67,69] can be fitted, both assigned to W6+, and a signal corresponding to BE W5p3/2 in 40.6 eV. The changes in W4f of the interfaces can be complemented by following the transformations of O1s in these cases. The fitting results of this region for Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) and Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) fresh and used samples are shown in Supplementary Information (Figure S8). From this figure, little variation is observed in Pt/SiO2-TSA (40) before and after reaction, however Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) is visibly modified by reaction. Before reaction both samples show a main peak near 532.8 ± 0.1 eV from several sources, adsorbed H2O, OH, etc., one more in 533.6 ± 0.1 eV like single P-O or Si-O typical bond [75] and a little one near to 531.0 ± 0.1 eV assigned to oxygen bonded to a W with high oxidation state [67]. This signal vanishes in Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) used and another one appears in 534.3 eV. R. K. Brow [76] found this signal from zinc borophosphate glasses, assigned it to P-O-P species, and established a relationship between P-O-P/P-O and metal oxide mole fraction. Brow showed that as metal oxide mole fraction increases, P-O-P/P-O decreases in Zn(1-x) P2O5 glasses. Following this idea, the depletion of the W quantity followed by W5+ signal lack, together with WO3 appearance and a change in O1s on Me-O signal from low to a high BE typical from P-O-P in Pt/SiO2-TPA (40) suggests a rearrangement or a breaking in P-Me or P-O-Me bond during reaction process. This fact would contribute to a leachate of W after each reaction cycle. In this sense, an analysis by atomic absorption spectroscopy revealed that no Pt leachate was found, but there is W leachate in both catalytic systems. In particular, the leachate is significant for the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalyst (40) that loses 44 %, 8 %, and 6 % by weight of the original W content in the first three reaction cycles. 4 Conclusions In this work, Pt catalysts supported on SiO₂ modified with tungstophosphoric (TPA) or tungstosilicic (TSA) acids were synthesized and evaluated for glycerol hydrogenolysis. The sol–gel synthesized SiO₂ support exhibited an amorphous, mesoporous structure with strong acid sites. The incorporation of TPA and TSA led to the formation of Keggin-type species: [PW12O40]3- and [H3-XPW12O40]X- for TPA, and [SiW12O40]4- for TSA, interacting with Si–OH2 + groups, and increased the density of strong acid sites with higher heteropolyacids loading (20–40 wt%). The presence of TPA and TSA improved Pt dispersion, yielding nanoparticles between 1.5 and 2.9 nm. Pt/SiO₂-TPA catalysts exhibited lower number of acid sites but of stronger acidity, composed mainly by [W2O7]2- and W2O5 species. In contrast, Pt/SiO₂-TSA catalysts showed a higher number of weaker acid sites, including [W2O6]2-, H4SiW12O40 and [W7O24]6- like species. Catalytic tests revealed that Pt/SiO₂-TPA catalysts were more active and selective toward 1,3-propanediol (1,3-PG) and 1-propanol (1-POH), while Pt/SiO₂-TSA catalysts showed greater stability. Selectivity towards 1-POH increased with heteropolyacids content and reaction temperature (180–220 °C), linked to a higher density of acid sites. A linear correlation was found between catalytic activity/selectivity and both the acid site density and average Pt particle size. Deactivation was more pronounced in Pt/SiO₂-TPA catalysts and was attributed to support sintering, glycerol adsorption, and W leaching. Stability tests confirmed better performance for Pt/SiO₂-TSA catalysts after five consecutive cycles. These findings demonstrate the role of heteropolyacid type and loading in tuning catalyst structure, acidity, and performance for glycerol valorization. coredata.dc:description: In this work, Pt catalysts were prepared using a sol-gel synthesized SiO2 modified by inclusion of tungstophosphoric acid (TPA) and tungstosilicic acid (TSA), which were evaluated in the glycerol hydrogenolysis in liquid phase to obtain 1,3-propylene glycol (1,3-PG) and 1-propanol (1-POH). The results showed that the SiO2 presents a mesoporous and amorphous structure which, modified by inclusion of TPA and TSA, exhibits [H3-xPW12O40]x- (x = 0–3) and [H4-xSiW12O40]x- (x = 0–4) anions with Keggin structure type. The inclusion of TPA or TSA generates strong acid sites and enhances Pt dispersion in the Pt/SiO2-TPA and Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts, which have smaller and similar particle sizes ranging from 1.5 to 2.9 nm depending on the heteropolyacid content. On their surface, the Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts present a low number of strong acid sites composed by [W2O7]2- and W2O5 species while the Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts present a greater number of sites, but with lower acid strength, composed mainly by [W2O6]2-, H4SiW12O40 and [W7O24]−6 species. The Pt/SiO2-TPA catalysts were more active but less stable than the Pt/SiO2-TSA catalysts, both series being selective to 1,3-PG and 1-POH. The sintering of the support, the adsorption of glycerol molecules and the leaching of W were identified as the main causes of deactivation.

coredata.dc:title: Simultaneous production of 1,3-propylene glycol and 1-propanol trough glycerol hydrogenolysis: Pt catalysts supported on heteropolyacids-modified mesoporous silica
